title: The Three Doctors
dialogue_triumphs: The First Doctor: 'So, you're my replacements? A dandy and a clown!'
dialogue_disasters: A UNIT Corporal has his first encounter with alien life: 'Holy Moses! What's that?!'
The Brigadier in an oft-quoted fit of pique: 'Liberty Hall, Dr Tyler, Liberty Hall!'
goofs: The Brigadier says UNIT HQ is 'a top secret establishment'. It's therefore a surprise to see a large sign outside informing the world not only of its function, but also the name of the commanding officer.
Reflections from the studio are often visible on the TARDIS monitor (and the second Doctor is reflected in the time rotor before he appears).
The footsteps of those returning to Earth via the singularity can be heard as they walk down the steps after they've disappeared.
Jo's knickers can be seen in episode one.

continuity_notes.description: A law forbidding Time Lords from crossing their own time-stream and meeting their former or future selves.
continuity_notes.current_status: Broken by the President of the Time Lords

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor's Exile
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's punishment by the Time Lords, preventing him from time-traveling.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS

technobabble: The Brigadier's description of the X-rays taken by Tyler as 'space lightning' prompts the Doctor to guess at 'a sort of controlled superlucent emission'.
links: The Brigadier mentions his previous meetings with the second Doctor and the events of 'Spearhead from Space', but the Doctor is ignorant of the Autons, saying: 'As far as I'm concerned, it hasn't happened yet.'

additional_notes: Fashion Victims: Jo in a blue fur coat, mini-skirt and platform boots. Just the sort of sensible footwear needed for a rocky alien planet.
bottom_line: An exercise in nostalgia, which both demystifies and changes the nature of Doctor Who, 'The Three Doctors' hasn't aged well. It's gaudy and it has a smug edge to it, as though the fact that it is an anniversary means that nobody has to try too hard. But the Troughton/Pertwee interplay makes up for this, almost excusing the sight of a clearly ill William Hartnell reduced to an image on a screen.
